'''''Baorangia bicolor''''', also known as the '''two-colored bolete''' or '''red and yellow bolete''' after its two-tone coloring scheme of red and yellow, is an [[edible mushroom|edible]] [[fungus]] in the genus ''[[Baorangia]]''. It inhabits most of eastern [[North America]], primarily east of the [[Rocky Mountains]] and in season during the summer and fall months but can be found across the globe in China and Nepal. Its fruit body, the [[mushroom]], is classed as medium or large in size, which helps distinguish it from the many similar appearing species that have a smaller stature. A deep blue/indigo bruising of the pore surface and a less dramatic bruising coloration change in the [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] over a period of several minutes are identifying characteristics that distinguish it from the similar [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] species ''[[Boletus sensibilis]]''. There are two variations of this species, variety ''borealis'' and variety ''subreticulatus'', and several other similar species of fungi are not poisonous.

== Taxonomy and naming ==
''Baorangia bicolor'' was originally named in 1807 by the Italian botanist [[Giuseppe Raddi]].<ref name=Raddi1807>{{Harv|Raddi|1807|pages=62–345}}</ref> American mycologist [[Charles Horton Peck]] named a species collected in Sandlake, [[New York (U.S. state)|New York]], in 1870, ''Boletus bicolor''. Although this naming is considered illegitimate due to [http://ibot.sav.sk/icbn/no%20frames/0058Ch5RejoNa53.htm article 53.1] of the [[International Code of Botanical Nomenclature]],<ref name="urlFungorum: Boletus bicolor"/> Peck is still given as the authority in the Bessette ''et al''. (2000) [[monograph]] of North American boletes.<ref name=Bessett2000>{{Harv|Bessette|2000|pages=97–98}}</ref>  ''Boletus bicolor'' (Raddi) is not a [[synonym (biology)|synonym]] of "Boletus bicolor" Peck.<ref name="urlMycoBank: Boletus bicolor"/><ref name="urlMycoBank: Boletus bicolor Raddi">{{cite web |title=''Boletus bicolor'' Raddi, Memorie di Matematica e di Fisica della Società Italiana di Scienze Residente in Modena, 13 (2): 352, t. 5:4, 1807 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/BioloMICS.aspx?Table=Mycobank&Rec=236233&Fields=All |publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association |accessdate=2013-05-09}}</ref>  Peck's ''Boletus bicolor'' describes the Eastern North American species that is the familiar "two-colored bolete", while Raddi's ''Boletus bicolor'' describes a separate European species that is lost to science.<ref name="Snell 1941">{{cite journal |author1=Snell, W.H. |author2=Dick, E.A. |title=Notes on Boletes. VI |journal=Mycologia |year=1941 |volume=33 |issue=1 |pages=23–37 |url=http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/cyberliber/59350/0033/001/0033.htm |doi=10.2307/3754732 |access-date=2013-05-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923222922/http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/cyberliber/59350/0033/001/0033.htm |archive-date=2015-09-23 |url-status=dead |jstor=3754732 }}</ref>  This [[taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] conflict has yet to be resolved. In 1909 a species found in Singapore was named ''Boletus bicolor'' by [[George Edward Massee]];<ref name=Massee1909>{{Harv|Massee|1909|pages=9–204}}</ref> this naming is illegitimate and is synonymous with ''Boletochaete bicolor'' according to Singer.<ref name=Singer1986/><ref name="urlMycoBank: Boletus bicolor Massee 1909">{{cite web |title=''Boletus bicolor'' Massee 1909 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=206292 |publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association |accessdate=January 4, 2012}}</ref> Molecular studies found that ''Boletus bicolor'' was not closely related to the [[type (biology)|type species]] of ''Boletus'', ''[[Boletus edulis]]'', and in 2015 Alfredo Vizzini transferred ''Boletus bicolor'' to the genus ''[[Baorangia]]''.<ref name="Nuhn 2013"/><ref name="Wu 2014"/><ref name="Vizzini 2015"/> The original [[botanical name]] for this two-colored bolete was derived from the [[Latin]] words ''bōlētus'', meaning "mushroom",<ref name="boletus">{{Cite web|title=bōlētus|publisher=Perseus Digital Library|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059%3Aalphabetic+letter%3DB%3Aentry+group%3D16%3Aentry%3Dboletus|accessdate=December 17, 2011}}</ref> and ''bicolor'', meaning "having two colors."<ref name="bicolor">{{Cite web|title=bicolor|publisher=Perseus Digital Library|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/resolveform?type=exact&lookup=bicolor&lang=la|accessdate=December 17, 2011}}</ref>

== Description ==
[[File:Two-Color Bolete downside.jpg|thumb|left|The pore surface of ''B. bicolor'' is bright yellow.]]
The color of the [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of the two-colored [[bolete]] varies from light red and almost pink to brick red. The most common coloration is brick red when mature. The cap usually ranges from {{convert|5|cm|in|abbr=on}} to {{convert|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} in width, with bright yellow pores underneath. The two-colored bolete is one of several types of boletes that have the unusual reaction of the [[hymenium|pore surface]] producing a dark blue/indigo when it is injured, although the reaction is slower than with other bluing boletes. When the [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is exposed it also turns a dark blue, but less dramatically than the pore surface.<ref name="Wernert 1982 p">{{Harv |Wernert|1982| p=}}</ref> Young [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] have bright yellow pore surfacesthat slowly turn a dingy yellow in maturity.

The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] of the two-colored bolete ranges from {{convert|5|cm|in|abbr=on}} to {{convert|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} in length and ranges from {{convert|1|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} to {{convert|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in width. The stem coloration is yellow at the apex and a red or rosy red for the lower two thirds. When injured it bruises blue very slowly and may hardly change color at all in some cases. The stem lacks a [[Annulus (mycology)|ring]] and lacks a [[partial veil]].<ref name="Bessette">{{Harv|Bessette|2000|page=97}}</ref>

=== Microscopic characteristics ===
The [[spore deposit]] of the two-colored bolete is olive-brown. Viewed with a [[light microscopy|microscope]], the [[spore]]s are slightly oblong to [[ventricose]] in face view; in profile view, the spores are roughly inequilateral to oblong, and have a shallow [[hilum (biology)|suprahilar depression]]. The spores appear nearly [[hyaline]] (translucent) to pale dingy [[ochraceous]] when mounted in [[potassium hydroxide]] solution (KOH), have a smooth surface, and measure 8–12 by 3.5–5 [[micrometre|μm]]. The tube [[trama (mycology)|trama]] is [[wikt:divergent gill trama|divergent]] and gelatinous, originates from a single central strand, not [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]], and will often stain yellow-brown when placed in dilute [[potassium hydroxide]] (KOH).<ref name="Hanchett">{{Harv|Bessette|1971|page=275}}</ref>

=== Chemical tests ===
Further methods of identification are [[Chemical tests in mushroom identification|chemical tests]]. With the application of [[FeSO4|FeSO<sub>4</sub>]] to the cap cuticle ([[pileipellis]]), it will turn a dark grey, almost black color and with the application of potassium hydroxide or [[NH4OH|NH<sub>4</sub>OH]] it has a negative coloration. The [[context (mycology)|context]] stains a bluish grey to an olive green when FeSO<sub>4</sub> is applied to it, a pale orange to a pale yellow with the application of KOH, and negative with the application of NH<sub>4</sub>OH.<ref name="Bessette"/>

== Edibility ==
The two-colored bolete is an [[edible mushroom]], although some may have an allergic reaction after ingestion that results in stomach upset.<ref name=Roger>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5608.asp |last=Phillips |first=Roger |publisher=RogersMushrooms |title=Boletus bicolor |accessdate=October 24, 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106110228/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5608.asp |archivedate=November 6, 2011 }}</ref> The mushroom has a very mild to no taste<ref name="New Jersey Mycological">{{Cite web|title=Boletus bicolor|publisher=New Jersey Mycological Association|url=http://www.njmyco.org/mushpages/Boletus_bicolor.html|accessdate=October 20, 2011}}</ref> although it is said to have a very distinctive taste like that of the [[king bolete]]. It can be cooked several ways, and the varying color of the cap can be used to determine if the mushroom is ready to be eaten. If the cap is a lighter red, then it is less mature and is in a stage where it is often larva infested or it can be soft fleshed, in some cases both. The cap should have a dark brick red color when safe to eat.<ref name=mushroomreport>{{cite web|url=http://www.silysavg.com/naturespickings/mushroomreport/two_colored_bolete.html|last=Report|first=Mushroom|publisher=Mushroom Report|title=Boletus bicolor|accessdate=October 24, 2011}}</ref> Drying the two-colored bolete is a good method for storage. It is important to note the time it takes for the two-colored bolete to bruise when identifying it for consumption; the mushroom should take several minutes to bruise compared to the instant bruising of ''Boletus sensibilis'', which is poisonous and has many of the same visual characteristics of the two-colored bolete.<ref name="Roger"/>

== Distribution and habitat ==
The two-colored bolete is distributed from southeastern Canada and the [[Great Lakes Region]], primarily east of the Rocky Mountains, as far south as the Florida peninsula, and out to the  [[Midwest]] as far as [[Wisconsin]]. It is commonly found in [[Deciduous|deciduous woodland]] and usually grows under or close to [[broad-leaved tree]]s, especially [[oak]].<ref name="Wernert 1982 p"/> It can be found in isolation and in groups or clusters, primarily during June through October.<ref name="Bessette2">{{Harv|Bessette|2000|page=98}}</ref> The two-colored bolete is also found in China and Nepal, where it is one of the most used mushrooms of over 200 species of edible mushrooms used in Nepal.<ref name="Christensen">{{Harv|Christensen|2008}}</ref> This unusual distribution of the two-colored bolete and other mushrooms is known as the [[Grayan disjunction]]; the phenomenon is characterized by a species living in one continent or island and then also on the other side of the world with no specimens of the species living in between the specific habitats. The Grayan disjunction is not uncommon among fungi.<ref name="Vasilyeva">{{Harv|Vasilyeva|2010|page=284}}</ref>

== Similar species ==
[[File:Bol.rub.jpg|thumb|right|''Hortiboletus rubellus'']]
The two-colored bolete has several species that are similar to it and the differences are minute in most cases. ''Boletus sensibilis'' differs from the two-colored bolete in that it has an immediate bruising reaction and is poisonous, causing stomach upset if ingested, and in some cases a severe allergic reaction.<ref name=Kuo>{{cite web|url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/boletus_bicolor.html |title=''Boletus bicolor''|accessdate=October 19, 2011 |last=Kuo|first=Michael |year=2003 |work=MushroomExpert.Com Web }}</ref><ref name=Lamoureux>{{cite web|url=http://www.mycomontreal.qc.ca/english/portraits_en/BolBic_e.htm |title=Fungus Portraits No.2. Two-colored BoleteBoletus bicolor |accessdate=October 19, 2011 |last=Lamoureux |first=Yves |year=2009 |work=Le Cercle des mycologues de Montréal (CMM) |publisher=Le Mycologue |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002014802/http://www.mycomontreal.qc.ca/english/portraits_en/BolBic_e.htm |archivedate=October 2, 2011 }}</ref> ''[[Boletus miniato-olivaceus|B. miniato-olivaceus]]'' has a full yellow stem and slightly lighter cap coloration. It also has a more immediate bruising reaction than the two-colored bolete and the stem is slightly longer in proportion to the cap.<ref name="Coker">{{Harv|Coker|1974|page=64}}</ref> ''[[Boletus peckii|B. peckii]]'' differs from the two-colored bolete by having a smaller average size, a rose red cap that turns almost brown with age, flesh that is paler in color, and a bitter taste. ''[[Boletus speciosus|B. speciosus]]'' differs from the two-colored bolete by having a fully reticulated stem, more brilliant colors, and very narrow cylindrical spores.<ref name="Coker2">{{Harv|Coker|1974|page=65}}</ref> ''[[Hortiboletus rubellus]]'' subsp. ''rubens'' and the two-colored bolete have been found to have almost no difference between them, and they cannot be distinguished by appearance alone.<ref name="Coker"/> ''[[Boletus bicoloroide]]'' is very similar to the two-colored bolete, the major differences between them being ''B. bicoloroide'' has only been found in Michigan and has larger spores. ''B. bicoloroide'' is also slightly larger than the two-colored bolete, around {{convert|1|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} longer in the stem and {{convert|1|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in the cap. This species has not been as thoroughly researched as the two-colored bolete, thus macrochemical tests, edibility, distribution range, and the spore print color are all unknown.<ref name="Bessette3">{{Harv|Bessette|2000|page=99}}</ref>

== Varieties ==
There are two [[variety (botany)|varieties]] of the two-colored bolete: ''borealis'' and ''subreticulatus''.<ref name="Hanchett2">{{Harv|Bessette|1971|page=278}}</ref> Both varieties have a very similar habitat to that of the main species, except they appear to be limited to just the North American continent. Both varieties also have a slightly different coloration than that of the two-colored bolete, have deeper pores, and are not as often eaten or used in regional recipes.<ref name="Hanchett"/>

=== Variety ''borealis'' ===
Variety ''borealis'' has a slightly darker color scheme than the main species. The coloration in general is darker; the cap can vary from a bright apple red to a dark brick red with maturity, to almost purple in some instances. The pore surface has a varying coloration of orange red to red and becoming a dull brown red with age. The bruising coloration is a blue green and the spore print is olive brown. The distribution of variety ''borealis'' is relatively small, ranging from [[Michigan]] to the upper [[New England]] states. The similar distribution and coloration to ''[[Boletus carminiporus]]'' has caused the two to be confused.<ref name="Hanchett"/> New molecular evidence shows that ''borealis'' is not closely related to ''Baorangia bicolor'' var. ''bicolor''.<ref name="Nuhn 2013"/>

=== Variety ''subreticulatus'' ===
Variety ''subreticulatus'', like variety ''boralis'', has a generally darker coloration than the two-colored bolete, but varies much more than either. When fresh the coloration of the cap varies from a rose red, red, rose pink, dark red, and purple red. With age it changes to a cinnamon red or a rusty rose color, with yellowing toward the margin. The pore surface is similar to that of the main species–yellow when fresh and with age changing to a dull ochre yellow; the bruising coloration is blue but is much lighter and sometimes not appearing to stain when bruised at all. The spore print is olive brown.<ref name="Hanchett"/> The distribution of variety ''subreticulatus'' is very similar to the distribution of the two-colored bolete in North America, and appears north to eastern Canada and south to Florida, and west to Wisconsin.<ref name="Hanchett"/>
